items.title: Why the Department of War name is making a comeback
items.standfirst: President Trump began the process of renaming the Department of Defense to the Department of War. It's been more than 75 years since that name was used. CBS News' Aaron Navarro has more details.
items.content: President Trump began the process of renaming the Department of Defense to the Department of War. It's been more than 75 years since that name was used. CBS News' Aaron Navarro has more details.

items.title: Trump Signs Order to Rename Pentagon the Department of War
Trump signs executive order rebranding Pentagon as Department of War
items.standfirst: Directive will make Department of War secondary title and is way to get around need for congressional approvalDonald Trump signed an executive order on Friday to rebrand the Department of Defense as the Department of War, a callback to the department’s original name used from 1789 to 1947.The directive will make Department of War the secondary title, and is a way to get around the need for congressional approval to formally rename a federal agency, an administration official said. Continue reading...

items.title: Anthropic agrees to pay $1.5B US to settle author class action over AI training
items.standfirst: Anthropic told a San Francisco federal judge on Friday that it has agreed to pay $1.5 billion to settle a class-action lawsuit from a group of authors who accused the artificial intelligence company of using pirated copies of their books to train its AI chatbot, Claude, without permission.

items.title: Anthropic Agrees to Pay Authors at Least $1.5 Billion in AI Copyright Settlement
items.standfirst: Anthropic will pay at least $3,000 for each copyrighted work that it pirated. The company downloaded unauthorized copies of books in early efforts to gather training data for its AI tools.
items.content: Anthropic will pay at least $3,000 for each copyrighted work that it pirated. The company downloaded unauthorized copies of books in early efforts to gather training data for its AI tools.

items.title: Anthropic Reaches $1.5 Billion Author Copyright Settlement
items.standfirst: Anthropic PBC will pay at least $1.5 billion plus interest to resolve an authors’ copyright lawsuit over the AI company’s downloading of millions of pirated books, one of the largest settlements over artificial intelligence and intellectual property to date.
items.content: Anthropic PBC will pay at least $1.5 billion plus interest to resolve an authors’ copyright lawsuit over the AI company’s downloading of millions of pirated books, one of the largest settlements over artificial intelligence and intellectual property to date.

ai_summary: Anthropic agreed to pay $1.5 billion to settle a lawsuit with authors.
The lawsuit alleged Anthropic used pirated copies of books for AI training.
Authors will receive approximately $3,000 per book as part of the settlement.
The settlement is considered a landmark in AI copyright legal battles.
The settlement could mark a turning point in legal battles.

items.title: Putin says foreign troops in Ukraine would be legitimate targets

items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Friday thousands of foreign troops could be deployed to his country under post-war security guarantees, but Russian leader Vladimir Putin said Moscow would regard them as legitimate targets to attack.

items.title: Western troops in Ukraine would be ‘legitimate targets’, Putin says
items.standfirst: Russian president’s threat follows French proposal for postwar support for Kyiv that would include presence of Nato countries’ forcesVladimir Putin has said any western troops placed in Ukraine would be “legitimate targets” for Russian strikes, upping the stakes as Kyiv’s allies scramble to come up with a convincing offer of postwar support to Ukraine.Speaking a day after the French president, Emmanuel Macron, announced still-vague plans for a package of support for Ukraine backed by 26 nations, Putin on Friday said any guarantees that involved boots on the ground would violate Moscow’s longstanding objections to Nato troops in Ukraine. Continue reading...
items.content: Russian president’s threat follows French proposal for postwar support for Kyiv that would include presence of Nato countries’ forcesVladimir Putin has said any western troops placed in Ukraine would be “legitimate targets” for Russian strikes, upping the stakes as Kyiv’s allies scramble to come up with a convincing offer of postwar support to Ukraine.Speaking a day after the French president, Emmanuel Macron, announced still-vague plans for a package of support for Ukraine backed by 26 nations, Putin on Friday said any guarantees that involved boots on the ground would violate Moscow’s longstanding objections to Nato troops in Ukraine. items.title: Putin sends grave warning to Ukraine's allies over Western troop deployment

items.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin has said any foreign troops operating as part of a peacekeeping force in Ukraine would be considered a "legitimate target" by Moscow.

ai_summary: Putin stated foreign troops in Ukraine would be legitimate targets.
Putin rejected the idea of peacekeeping forces after a peace deal.
Putin's statement followed a French proposal for postwar support.
The French proposal included the potential presence of NATO forces.
Putin's comments escalated tensions regarding the conflict.

items.title: Trump threatens new tariffs over EU's $3.5 billion antitrust fine against Google
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Friday lashed out against the European Union’s $3.47 billion antitrust fine against Google as “unfair” and threatened retaliatory tariffs if the bloc does not reverse the penalty. Trump's rebuke came a day after he hosted tech leaders, including Google’s top executives, at a White House dinner.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Friday lashed out against the European Union’s $3.47 billion antitrust fine against Google as “unfair” and threatened retaliatory tariffs if the bloc does not reverse the penalty. Trump's rebuke came a day after he hosted tech leaders, including Google’s top executives, at a White House dinner.

items.title: Judge rules against Trump's attempt to end protections for Venezuelans, Haitians

items.content: U.S. District Judge Edward Chen ruled against the Trump administration in a challenge to its effort to end the Temporary Protected Status program for roughly 1 million Venezuelan and Haitian migrants.

items.standfirst: The ruling by U.S. District Judge Edward Chen of San Francisco for the plaintiffs means 600,000 Venezuelans whose temporary protections expired in April or whose protections were about to expire Sept. 10 have status to stay and work in the United States. It also keeps protections for about 500,000…
items.content: The ruling by U.S. District Judge Edward Chen of San Francisco for the plaintiffs means 600,000 Venezuelans whose temporary protections expired in April or whose protections were about to expire Sept. 10 have status to stay and work in the United States. It also keeps protections for about 500,000…

items.title: Judge blocks ending of legal protections for 1m Venezuelans and Haitians in US
items.standfirst: Homeland security had tried to end temporary protected status granted by the Biden administrationA federal judge on Friday ruled against the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections that have granted more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela the right to live and work in the United States.The ruling by US district judge Edward Chen of San Francisco for the plaintiffs means that 600,000 Venezuelans whose temporary protections expired in April or whose protections were about to expire on 10 September have status to stay and work in the United States. Continue reading...
items.content: Homeland security had tried to end temporary protected status granted by the Biden administrationA federal judge on Friday ruled against the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections that have granted more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela the right to live and work in the United States.The ruling by US district judge Edward Chen of San Francisco for the plaintiffs means that 600,000 Venezuelans whose temporary protections expired in April or whose protections were about to expire on 10 September have status to stay and work in the United States. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A judge ruled against ending protections for Venezuelans and Haitians.
The ruling impacts roughly 1 million migrants.
The ruling prevents the end of Temporary Protected Status.
600,000 Venezuelans can continue to stay and work in the US.
The ruling protects about 500,000 Haitians.

items.title: Google hit with $3.5 billion fine from European Union in ad-tech antitrust case
items.standfirst: By KELVIN CHAN European Union regulators on Friday hit Google with a 2.95 billion euro ($3.5 billion) fine for breaching the bloc’s competition rules by favoring its own digital advertising services, but the bloc’s latest move to crack down on Big Tech companies drew outrage from President Donald…
items.content: By KELVIN CHAN European Union regulators on Friday hit Google with a 2.95 billion euro ($3.5 billion) fine for breaching the bloc’s competition rules by favoring its own digital advertising services, but the bloc’s latest move to crack down on Big Tech companies drew outrage from President Donald…

items.title: EU fines Google nearly €3bn for ‘abusing’ dominant position in ad tech
items.standfirst: Regulators ordered the tech giant to end ‘self-preferencing practices’ in advertising services but declined to force saleEuropean Union regulators on Friday hit Google with a €2.95bn ($3.5bn) fine for breaching the bloc’s competition rules by favoring its own digital advertising services, marking the fourth such antitrust penalty for the company as well as a retreat from previous threats to break up the tech giant.The European Commission, the 27-nation bloc’s executive branch and top antitrust enforcer, also ordered the US company to end its “self-preferencing practices” and take steps to stop “conflicts of interest” along the advertising technology supply chain. Continue reading...
items.content: Regulators ordered the tech giant to end ‘self-preferencing practices’ in advertising services but declined to force saleEuropean Union regulators on Friday hit Google with a €2.95bn ($3.5bn) fine for breaching the bloc’s competition rules by favoring its own digital advertising services, marking the fourth such antitrust penalty for the company as well as a retreat from previous threats to break up the tech giant.The European Commission, the 27-nation bloc’s executive branch and top antitrust enforcer, also ordered the US company to end its “self-preferencing practices” and take steps to stop “conflicts of interest” along the advertising technology supply chain. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The European Union fined Google 2.95 billion euros ($3.5 billion).
The fine was for breaching competition rules in digital advertising.
Google was ordered to end "self-preferencing practices."
The EU also ordered Google to stop "conflicts of interest."

items.title: Anutin Charnvirakul elected prime minister of Thailand in parliamentary vote
items.standfirst: Anutin, 58, succeeds Paetongtarn Shinawatra, who was dismissed by court order as prime minister last week after being found guilty of ethics violations over a politically compromising phone call with neighboring Cambodia’s Senate President Hun Sen.
items.content: Anutin, 58, succeeds Paetongtarn Shinawatra, who was dismissed by court order as prime minister last week after being found guilty of ethics violations over a politically compromising phone call with neighboring Cambodia’s Senate President Hun Sen.

items.title: Tycoon who led push to decriminalise cannabis becomes Thai PM
items.standfirst: Anutin Charnvirakul voted in by parliament after promising election in four months, as Thaksin Shinawatra jets outAnutin Charnvirakul, a staunch royalist, has been appointed by lawmakers as Thailand’s next prime minister after days of heated negotiations and political drama.The 58-year-old tycoon turned politician is considered a conservative, though he made a name for himself for leading a campaign to decriminalise cannabis. He was voted in after a chaotic scramble by parties to gain enough support to replace the ousted PM, Paetongtarn Shinawatra, who was removed from office by a court ruling. Continue reading...
items.content: Anutin Charnvirakul voted in by parliament after promising election in four months, as Thaksin Shinawatra jets outAnutin Charnvirakul, a staunch royalist, has been appointed by lawmakers as Thailand’s next prime minister after days of heated negotiations and political drama.The 58-year-old tycoon turned politician is considered a conservative, though he made a name for himself for leading a campaign to decriminalise cannabis. He was voted in after a chaotic scramble by parties to gain enough support to replace the ousted PM, Paetongtarn Shinawatra, who was removed from office by a court ruling. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Anutin Charnvirakul, 58, was elected prime minister of Thailand.
He succeeds Paetongtarn Shinawatra, who was dismissed by court order.
Anutin led a campaign to decriminalize cannabis.
He was voted in after a chaotic scramble by parties.

items.title: Trump sends 10 stealth fighter planes to Puerto Rico amid war on Caribbean drug cartels
items.standfirst: Move comes after US accuses Venezuela of buzzing warship and a deadly US missile strike in Caribbean SeaDonald Trump is sending 10 F-35 fighter jets to Puerto Rico to bolster US military operations against drug cartels in the Caribbean region, it was reported on Friday.If follows a deadly US missile strike on Tuesday on a boat in the Caribbean Sea that the Trump administration insisted was carrying 11 Venezuelan drug traffickers, and comments by the secretary of state, Marco Rubio, on Wednesday that such attacks “will happen again”. items.title: US deploys fighter jets to Puerto Rico to combat drug cartels amid tensions with Venezuela
